description.narrative: 1. Existence of Country Action Agenda and Investment Prospectus 2. Existence of strategies and regulatory framework for off-grid electrification 3. Existence of energy database and information system 4. Data management and modelling software utilized by stakeholders 5. Disbursement of funds from FSS for establishment of mini-grids and energy centres 6. Availability of business model for off-grid electrification 7. 10 mini-grids and 10 Energy Centres operational 8. Existence of an outreach programme for the project

comment.narrative: 1. No Country Action Agenda and Investment Prospectus in Lesotho 2. No strategies and regulatory framework to facilitate investment in RET and mini-grids for off-grid electrification. 3. No energy database and information system in Lesotho 4. Lack of capacity of stakeholders in energy data management and modelling 5. No financial mechanisms to facilitate private sector's investment in mini-grids and energy centres 6. No business models to facilitate private developers for off-grid electrification 7. Mini-grids and Energy Centres are non-existent 8. No outreach programme for dissemination of project results
Launch the SEA4ALL project

The SE4ALL project was launched in November 2016. The objective of the project is to catalyze investment in renewable energy-based mini-grids and Energy Centres to reduce GHG emissions and contribute to the achievement of Lesotho’s Vision 2020 and SE4All goals.

1. Country Action Agenda(CAA) and investment Prospectus(IP) developed within 12 months of project initiation 2. Sub-strategies and regulatory framework for off-grid electrification developed within 12 months of project initiation 3. National Energy Survey completed 4. Energy database and information system available within 12 months of project initiation 5. Capacity of stakeholders to manage data developed within 12 months of project initiation 6. Financial Support Scheme available and operational within 18 months of project initiation

3. National Household Energy Survey for both summer and winter completed. 4. Development of energy database in underway, and the final product is expected in January 2018. 5. Stakeholders including Department of Energy and Bureau of Statistics were capacitated and are able to clean and analyse energy data and produce energy balance for Lesotho. 6. Design of the Financial Support Scheme is complete. The to be operationalized in 2018.

description.narrative: 1) Number of communities with scaled up climate change interventions 2) Number of research progammes on impact of ongoing climate change adaptation measures 3) Facility to carry out production of biogas from sewage waste. 4) Number of climate related frameworks developed to address management of climate risk and natural shocks. 5) Environment Information Management System in place to inform evidence-based planning and decision making on environment management 6) Number of project concept notes developed and submitted for resources mobilization.

comment.narrative: 1) Twenty five (25) Community Based Organizations implementing climate change interventions identified for scaling up. 2) No research programme on the impact of ongoing climate change adaptation measures 3) There is no facility to carryout research on production of biogas from sewage waste as an alternative source of clean energy. 4) Government of Lesotho doesn’t have framework to guide management of climate related risks and natural shocks. 5) Lack of necessary capacity to inform evidence-based planning and decision making on environment management 6) $11.8 million mobilized for Climate Change implementation (2015).

1) Ten (10) climate change interventions implemented by communities scaled up. 2) Support National University of Lesotho (NUL) to upgrade its laboratory equipment for carrying out research progammes on impact of ongoing climate change adaptation measures. 3) Facility to carry out production of biogas 4) Support development of a National Strategic Resilience Framework document.
6) Development of Biodiversity project concept note to be submitted for GEF funding.

1) Through UNDP five (5) CBOs were supported with renewable energy technologies including solar dryers to scale up the on-going climate change interventions also to facilitate alternatives for diversifying their livelihoods. 2) UNDP provided National University of Lesotho (NUL) with equipment to carry out research progammes on the impact of Conservation Agriculture as climate change adaptation measure. 3) NUL supported to establish a facility to carry out research on production of biogas from sewage algae. 4) UNDP provided technical support to Government of Lesotho to develop a National Strategic Resilience Framework.
6) Developed and submitted a Biodiversity concept note for GEF funding.

1) Supprt scaling up of fifteen (15) climate change interventions implemented by local communities. 2) Support NUL to collect data for analyzing impact of ongoing climate change adaptation measures. 3) Support production and bottling of biogas. 4) Support finalization of the National Strategic Resilience Framework document. 5) Support Government of Lesotho through Ministry of Tourism, Environment and Culture to develop an Environment Information System Management. 6) Review GEF comments on Biodiversity project concept note and resubmit.

2) Supported NUL to collect data for analyzing impact of ongoing climate change adaptation measures.
4) Development of the National Strategic Resilience Framework document was finalized. 5) Capacity building including development of data collection tools for management of environmental data through Environment Information Management System completed. 6) The Biodiversity project concept note resubmitted and got GEF approval.

Support a consultative process to deliver comprehensive and participatory reforms by all stakeholders.
THIS OUTPUT WAS OPERATIONALLY CLOSED IN JULY 2017.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
Mechanisms for constructive engagement and dialogue for successful reform agenda.

comment.narrative: 1. Commonwealth Report on the Study Tour to New Zealand 2014 2. Coalition Government Agreement 2015 3. SADC Commission of Inquiry Report 2016.
1. Consultations on Reforms Agenda agreed upon with all stakeholders 2. Reforms Programme launched

1.1 support to the ruling coalition government in the development of options towards the review of the constitution and execution of sector reforms. UNDP's technical support through a constitutional expert and process support through a dialogue and consensus building expert in early 2016 led to the development of road maps for the constitutional review process and for security sector reforms, culminating in the launch of the Lesotho Reforms Programme in December. Secondly, 1.2 UNDP supported civil society organizations to develop an Advocacy strategy for their involvement in the proposed national reforms. The strategy document was developed, validated and accepted by a majority of civil society organizations and has since been presented to the government and the public.
Provide financial and technical assistance to the Lesotho Reforms Programme focusing on Constitutional, Security Sector, Public Service Sector, Parliamentary and Judicial Reforms.
OUTPUT CLOSED
OUTPUT CLOSED
OUTPUT CLOSED

description.narrative: Programme on Reform of Governance, Rights & Empowerment for Sustained Stability (PROGRESS)
capital of a political entity
Human rights affairs

1.Mechanisms for constructive engagement and dialogue for successful reform agenda in place. 2.Voter education undertaken to raise awareness of the electorate on the electoral processes and number Needs Assessment Mission (NAM) recommendations implemented. 3..Extent to which the parliament mainstreams Sustainable Development Goals in parliamentary business and research unit operational. 4. National Human Rights Commission in place, number of Universal Periodic Review recommendations implemented and number of treaty body reports submitted. 5.Number of strategies adopted to mitigate sector specific corruption risk. 6.Number of facilitated dialogue sessions for conflict resolution (at local and national levels) and extend to which sustainable peace infrastructures are established. 7.Extent of youth / women engagement and participation in policy and legal frameworks development

comment.narrative: 1.No documents developed on concrete mechanisms for Reforms Agenda except recommendations of the Commonwealth Report on the Study Tour to New Zealand 2014, Coalition Government Agreement 2015, Southern African Development Community (SADC) Commission of Inquiry Report 2016, 2. Voters’ limited awareness of their rights and responsibilities in electoral matters. 3. MPs lacking awareness on SDGs and lack of research skills and expertise. 4. National Human Rights Commission Act legislated; 137 accepted UPR recommendations; 8 reports overdue to UN human rights system. 5. The National Anti-Corruption Strategy and Action Plan (NACSAP) 2014 -2019 6. No national peace infrastructure 7. Youth Policy 1995, National Human Development Report (NHDR) 2015

1. Support to the National Reform Agenda 2. Capacity building activities for IEC to run 2016 Local Government Elections 3. Support Parliamentary Engagement on SDGs and enhance capacity on research skills 4.An independent National Human Rights Commission established by Q4 2016; Roadmap drawn toward UPR implementation 5.. Implementation of the National Anti-Corruption Strategy and Action Plan (NACSAP) initiated 6. Local peace committees established and national consultations held. 7. Increased women and youth participation

1.1 UNDP engaged a Consensus Building Expert to develop a Reforms Options Paper and Road Map. 1.2 Local Government Elections were postponed to 2017 1.3 The training on SDGs for MPs ensured that the legislature is fully on board in their implementation by ensuring MPs' awareness of the SDGs and the roles of legislators in the development policies and plans drawn up in participatory and inclusive processes; interrogation of government budget allocations; ensuring that regular progress reports are submitted to Parliament for review. UNDP also provided support to translate an SDGs booklet into Sesotho to deepen MPs' understanding of the goals and Agenda 2030, and consequently their dissemination to their constituents as part of their advocacy role. 1.4 In collaboration with OHCHR, UNDP delivered training on the UN Human Rights Mechanisms and reporting leading to enhanced capacity within the country’s human rights institutions UNDP supported a study tour to the Kenya National Commission on Human Rights by key government of Lesotho officials to learn from the Kenyan experience on establishing a human rights institution. This study tour yielded a number of recommendations for the Government. UNDP supported the training of Parliamentary staff in research skills which led to the establishment of the Research Unit of Parliament. An institutionalized research capability in now in place for the first time in the history of Lesotho Parliament. The Unit is now assisting MPs to carry out legislative scrutiny, investigations, fact finding missions and constituency visits effectively. 1.5 The Implementation of key priority areas of the National Anti-Corruption and Strategy and Action Plan was a significant milestone in 2016. This was done through a series of sector-based review consultation where concerted strategies to combat corruption were agreed upon. This was an unprecedented coherent, forward-looking and integrated local framework to address challenges in fighting

1.Support to Local Government Elections. 2.Training of Members of Parliament and staff on thematic / specialised areas. 3. Support to the Human Rights Unit in implementing UPR and efforts towards operationalization of the National Human Rights Commission 4.Implementation of selected areas of the National Anti-Corruption Strategy and Action Plan (NACSAP) 5. Establishment of peace infrastructures and advocacy for youth empowerment and gender equality

1.National Assembly Elections. UNDP provided technical expertise in Logistics, IT for Display of Results, Analysis and Mitigation and a Graphic Designer. Changed focus from Local to supporting National Elections. 2.Parliament closed in August to enable support Local Government Elections and when it reconvened there was no time for activities and Parliamentary officials requested the 3. Support to Human Rights Unit with advocacy and outreach programmes in the districts as well as other UPR/Human Rights Body Treaties-State Party Reports. 4.Implementation of selected areas of the National Anti-Corruption Strategy and Action Plan by rolling out the asset declaration initiative and sensitization workshops. 5. Local Peace Committee in Ribaneng, Mafeteng established and National Youth Policy reviewed to pave the way for developing an Action Plan and preparing or Youth Elections in 2018,

Support to the National Reforms processes
Training of IEC staff in conflict resolution and development of a manual in Disputes Resolution
Training of Senate Committee Chairpersons and Clerks
Conduct Peoples Assembly on the role of the Senate

Support to operationalize the National Human Rights Commission
Implementation of UPR recommendations; National Mechanism for state party reporting in place
Implementation of selected areas of the National Anti-Corruption Strategy and Action Plan

comment.narrative: 1. Capacities of youth leaders are low to strengthen the youth-led organizations and their activities 2. No consultation with Political Party Youth Groups in regards to SDGs and developmental issues in Lesotho

1. Trainings are organized and held on national and local level for youth facilitators regarding on SDGs 2. Understanding on SDGs principles, importance of youth participation, and developmental issues in Lesotho

1.1 Briefing meetings were held with key government ministers, principal secretaries and senior technical officers on the one level while at another with Heads of Churches and civil society leaders. The challenge remained the multiple reshuffles of government personnel and instability in the ruling coalition government which slowed down the progress towards a national stakeholder conference on the establishment of the national mechanism.
1.2There was success in support to local level peacebuilding infrastructure in the volatile community of Ribaneng in the district of Mafeteng. Support to local religious leaders there lead to the formation of the Ribaneng Peace Committee as an early warning and response mechanism.
